commit.message:
Fix exception that can occur when a minifier object is reused.

Ensure the state of the minifier object is properly and fully reset.

fixes #46
Update documentation for 0.1.11
Version 0.1.11

Copy Python3's HTMLParser so that we can override its unescape behavior.

We have to copy it instead of monkeypatching it because we don't want to
have sideffects outside of our library.

Support prefixing attributes with 'pre-'. Fixes #17, #37

Support turning off attribute decoding.

Don't escape properly formed attribute encodings.
Merge branch 'mina86-master'
Cleanup some of the code found in mina86's wonderful change.o

Merge branch 'master' of https://github.com/mina86/htmlmin into mina86-master

Conflicts:
	htmlmin/escape.py
	htmlmin/tests/test_escape.py
	htmlmin/tests/tests.py
Precompile one of the regexes used and add more tests.

Merge pull request #34 from avacariu/master

Leave quotes around attributes containing =, <, >, and `

Remove redundant lang attributes

If tag’s lang attribute matches it’s parent language, the attribute is
redundant and can be removed.

Replace lambda with direct code in build_tag

Calling a lambda appears relatively costly in Python.  Replace it with
inline code in the build_tag method to gain some minor speed
improvements.

Before:
    35995    0.151    0.000    0.444    0.000 parser.py:112(build_tag)
    35995    0.163    0.000    0.473    0.000 parser.py:112(build_tag)
    35995    0.152    0.000    0.443    0.000 parser.py:112(build_tag)

    Ran 82 tests in 0.400s
    Ran 82 tests in 0.405s
    Ran 82 tests in 0.387s

After:
    35995    0.146    0.000    0.429    0.000 parser.py:112(build_tag)
    35995    0.148    0.000    0.430    0.000 parser.py:112(build_tag)
    35995    0.147    0.000    0.428    0.000 parser.py:112(build_tag)

    Ran 82 tests in 0.395s
    Ran 82 tests in 0.389s
    Ran 82 tests in 0.383s

Roll ‘has_pre’ checking into build_tag method

Avoid iterating over attributes list multiple times by pushing the
check whether a PRE attribute is present on the tag into the build_tag
method which already iterates over the list.

Furthermore, if keep_pre is False, with this change generating of
a copy of the attributes list is avoided.

This results in some small performance gains:

Before:
    35946    0.227    0.000    0.732    0.000 parser.py:223(handle_starttag)
    35946    0.229    0.000    0.733    0.000 parser.py:223(handle_starttag)
    35946    0.228    0.000    0.730    0.000 parser.py:223(handle_starttag)

After:
    35946    0.208    0.000    0.723    0.000 parser.py:228(handle_starttag)
    35946    0.207    0.000    0.714    0.000 parser.py:228(handle_starttag)
    35946    0.211    0.000    0.723    0.000 parser.py:228(handle_starttag)

Before:
    Ran 82 tests in 0.394s
    Ran 82 tests in 0.397s
    Ran 82 tests in 0.391s

After:
    Ran 82 tests in 0.384s
    Ran 82 tests in 0.380s
    Ran 82 tests in 0.388s

Optimise in_tag test

The old in_tag test essentially run a quadratic algorithm to test
whether one of set of tags was currently open.  This can be replaced
with a linear algorithm (assuming constant time dictionary access)
which speeds up the handle_starttag method.

In one test, the method got sped up by over 40%:

           ncalls  tottime  percall  cumtime  percall filename:lineno(function)
    Before: 35946    0.256    0.000    1.265    0.000 parser.py:208(handle_starttag)
    After:  35946    0.232    0.000    0.740    0.000 parser.py:223(handle_starttag)

htmlmin’s test suit itself was sped up by over 10%:

    Before: Ran 82 tests in 0.449s
    After: Ran 82 tests in 0.398s

Choose whether it’s better to use single or double quotes

If an attribute value contains more double quotes than single quotes it
is more efficient to quote the value using single quotes than double
quotes.  Count the quotes in the string and make decision based on that.

Quote attribute values if they contain disallowed characters

As per the stendard, unquoted attribute value cannot contain any of:
  " ' = < > `
or control characters (which include space characters).  Quote attribute
values which contain any of those characters.

This, sadly, results in worse minification.

Avoid regular expressions where simple string methods suffice

Instead of regex matching and substitution dealing with white space
characters, use string methods which acomplish the same effect.
Add ‘cls’ attribute to minify so custom HTMLMinParser can be used

Don’t add empty value to boolean attributes

If an attribute is passed as a boolean one (i.e. without value)
in the input text, do not add an empty value to it even if
reduce_empty_attributes is False.
Don’t include newline after a declaration

Refactor attribute quoting slightly

Refactor build_tag method slightly so that there are fewer cases to
consider.  Empty values are handled by the non-empty case (since
escape.escape_attr_value already correctly notices those need to be
quoted) and all cases for boolean attributes are put together.

Rearrange attributes to avoid unnecessary spaces

Unquoted attributes (e.g. ‘foo=bar’) require a space if they are to be
followed by a slash indicating a self-closing tag.  Similarly, due to
a bug in WebKit, unquoted attributes ending with a slash need a space
after them if they are the last attribute.

Rearrange attributes to mitigate those common pitfalls.

Merge pull request #40 from samupl/attributes-quote-xss

Fix xss risk if there is a html tag and remove optional attribute quotes is on

Merge pull request #38 from adamchainz/readthedocs.io

Convert readthedocs links for their .org -> .io migration for hosted projects

Merge pull request #35 from iffy/master

Fix encoding problem with python3

Merge pull request #41 from mercuree/comment_fix

Fixed index out of range error when comment is empty
Tests
Fixed ListIndex error when comment is empty
Fix xss risk if there is a html tag and remove optional attribute quotes is on

Convert readthedocs links for their .org -> .io migration for hosted projects

As per [their blog post of the 27th April](https://blog.readthedocs.com/securing-subdomains/) ‘Securing subdomains’:

> Starting today, Read the Docs will start hosting projects from subdomains on the domain readthedocs.io, instead of on readthedocs.org. This change addresses some security concerns around site cookies while hosting user generated data on the same domain as our dashboard.

Test Plan: Manually visited all the links I’ve modified.
